title: Do you think Linkin Park can continue as a group without Chester B? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. Though it will undoubtedly change the band dramatically. Shinoda has indicated that the Band intends to go on. But he has also said that as of now they have no idea what form that will take. This would not be the first time a band has replaced a beloved front man. In fact it happens all the time, and is often successful. even when the front man was the entire public face of the band, but especially when as in LP’s case, with Shinoda and Bennington, the band has multiple front men. People questioned Drowning Pool could go on after Dave Williams died, and their first attempt with Jason Jones was less than successful, but subsequently under Ryan McCombs and later Jasen Moreno they have found considerable renewed success. Adam Gontier’s departure from Three Days Grace raised similar reservations, and initially when Matt Walst attempted too much to emulate Gontier there were problems, but as Walst found his own voice the band has found renewed success, and in fact it was Gontier himself who struggled longer to return to popular consciousness before finding his footing with SΔINT ΔSONIΔ. Peter Gabriel replaced Phil Collins with considerable success. VH1 has a list of other such successful replacements here: Roll With the Changes: Ranking Rock’s Top 10 Replacement Lead Singers As a member of the LPU and Soldier (gah I still dislike the nickname for our fandom) from long ago, I admit to having a hard time imaging LP without Chester, but if Mike and Hahn say they intend to do it, then do I am sure they will do Chester proud.

At this point nobody knows. It is a very difficult position to be in. If they are to continue they would have to either do everything without Chester, or replace him. Neither of these possibilities seem right. How can you replace such a singer? And if you don’t, and you would have the public sing his parts, what sort of emotional rollercoaster should you expect? There is no telling ,as the band members of the band don’t know either. Speaking to Vulture last week, Shinoda said that he was “unable to say what will happen with the band”, adding: “There’s really just no answer, and it’s funny because if I even say anything about the band’s future, that becomes the headline, which is stupid because the answer is there is no answer.” “Fans think they want to know what the future is: Believe me, I want to know what the answer is. But there just isn’t one.” Read more at Mike Shinoda talks future of Linkin Park: "The answer is there is no answer" - NME

Of course they can continue. If they choose to do so, it’s mostly about how they go about it. There’s a lot of possibilities to that. If you’re interested, you can check out my ideas here. Personally, I can imagine Linkin Park doing releases in the far future. Maybe not so often. Maybe they wont even do full albums all that often. But, the guys have written together for so long, I can only imagine that they still show each other stuff and write with each other at least once in a while. No one’s to say that someone like Brad or Joe didn’t put in any ideas for Mike’s new album “Post Traumatic”. When it comes down to it, anythings possible. Linkin Park can continue. It won’t be the same, but really, with them, when has it?

Well Chester was and will remain one of the best vocalist music world would ever see. Linkin Park without Chester would never be possible. It is sad ,but in the end it is the truth. Mike Shinoda, the other band person who's the rapper ,is doing some good songs out there, under his new Post Traumatic EP.  OVER AND OVER AGAIN  ABOUT YOU. and the third, CROSSING THE LINE.

Yes, Linkin Park can continue as a band but they really need to hire a new vocalist as no one in the band can scream like Chester. They can hire Mark Wakefield, the former LP vocalist. To make rock music, they really need to hire a new vocalist.
That’s up to Mike and the band themselves to decide on. As of now Mike’s busy with his album Post Traumatic. So maybe.
